metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Asthma prolongs intubation in COVID-19 Title: Asthma prolongs intubation in COVID-19 1

abstract.text: Clinical Implications: Asthma was independently associated with prolonged duration of intubation for 26 . The co-occurrence of asthma with obesity, another predictor of poor outcome in these 104 intubation duration. This is clinically important since obesity, another predictor of poor outcome in 105 COVID-19 patients,(2) occurs more frequently in individuals with asthma (8, 9) . Therefore, coexistence 106 of these two factors places patients at a markedly higher risk of a worsened disease course from COVID-
19. This needs to be considered by all health care providers when triaging COVID-19 patients or 108 counselling asthmatic patients about COVID-19.

The main limitation of our study is that the asthma diagnoses were self-reported in some cases. All the 110 included individuals in our study were questioned whether they had "asthma" as part of an algorithm 111 for COVID-19 assessment. Further, in 73% of cases, we could find prior clinical documentation on 112 individuals' health and medical history such as primary care or specialty visit notes, up to date 113 medications lists and other work up for asthma in the medical records. These 73% were either 114 established patients at our health system or another health care systems across Chicago who were part 115 of "Care Everywhere" EPIC feature. Therefore, we were able to confirm the diagnosis of asthma by 116 reviewing the detailed past medical history of majority of our series by chart review. There was no 117 difference in the rate of asthma in patients with existing detailed past medical history and the rest of the 118 series who were asked and reported their asthma status as part of our COVID-19 algorithm. The overall 119 rate of asthma in our series (25.8%) is above the national average for asthma rate (8-11%) in adults. To identify and confirm these 46 diagnoses and clinical variables, all charts were reviewed by two independent trained researchers and 20% of the charts were randomly checked by the principal investigator, who is a board-certified 48 practicing allergist immunologist, to confirm the asthma diagnosis based on GINA guidlines

The initial series included 1003 patients who were tested by the on-demand COVID telemedicine clinic 60 or the emergency room through an algorithm for COVID-19, and had positive COVID-19 test results.

diagnosis of asthma. The rate of asthma was similar in all age groups (Table 1) . Asthma was significantly 64 associated with female gender and higher BMI ( Table 1) . Analysis of COVID-19 outcomes in association with asthma were carried out according to the CDC age groups and adjusted for demographic variables 66 and BMI.

Overall, among the whole series, asthma was significantly associated with longer intubation time; 68 mean± standard deviation(SD) of 10.17±6.9 and 5.28±5.9 days in asthmatic and non-asthmatics 69 respectively, p=0.002 (Table 1 ). The longer intubation time was present in both age groups of 18-49 yo 70 and 50-64 yo, but not in the age group of 65 yo and above. Duration of the hospitalization showed a 71 trend to be longer among patients with history of asthma compared to those without this history in 72 those aged 50-64 years (mean[SD] of 10.64[7.38] vs. 8.11 [5.26] in asthmatic vs. non-asthmatics, p=0.07), syndrome (8.9% vs. 9.5% in asthmatics vs. non-asthmatics, p=0.92) among COVID-19 patients. Peripheral patients. The published cohorts of COVID-19 from China did not include asthmatic patients (4, 5) . This trend towards longer hospitalization time and overall spent 2 more days in the hospital than the non-96 asthmatic in this age group. We believe that the duration of intubation is more reflective of the disease the longer intubation duration might indicate that asthma has the highest impact on COVID-19 course in 100 those younger than 65.

FIGREF0.text: of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly taking over the vast majority of 31 countries, overwhelming health care systems across the world. (1) The recent data from CDC indicate 32 that asthma is present in about 17% of all admitted COVID-19 patients in the US, and in as high as 27% 33 of patients in the age group of 20-49 years old, which marks asthma as the second most common 34 comorbidity in this age group, following obesity.(2) However the effect of asthma on the disease course 35 has not been reported yet. Considering that over 19 million adults in the U.S. have asthma, (3) it is 36 crucial to understand the impact of preexisting asthma on the course and outcome of COVID-19 37 infection. Here we report the result of our study on the role of asthma in the outcome of COVID-19 38 infection in a large cohort of COVID-19 positive patients.

FIGREF1.text: The study was approved by the Institutional Review Board of Rush University Medical Center. An

FIGREF3.text: 80 could be partially due to markedly lower rates of asthma in China (2-4%) compared to western countries 81 (8-11% in U.S). (3, 6) The effect of asthma on other virulent species of coronavirus that are associated 82 with SARS has not been studied either. However, members of the Coronaviridae family that are 83 associated with common cold have been linked to asthma exacerbations. (7)84In our series, history of asthma was neither associated with increased rate of acute respiratory distress 85 syndrome nor with hospitalization. However, among the patients who developed severe respiratory 86 symptoms requiring intubation, asthma was associated with a significantly longer intubation time.

FIGREF4.text: Asthma particularly prolonged the intubation time in younger (<65 yo) COVID-19 patients who are 88 otherwise shown to have a better disease course than the older patients. This data suggests that 89 younger individuals with asthma may require extra attention as they could develop a sustained 90 pulmonary failure with COVID-19 infection, leading to a prolonged mechanical ventilation. Per the ICU 91 protocol, all of our COVID-19 intubated patients were on nebulized albuterol and most were treated 92 with systemic steroids. To understand whether use of bronchodilators and systemic steroids might 93 impact the link between intubation time and asthma, we adjusted our analysis for albuterol and 94 systemic steroids use, which did not change our findings. TABREF0.text: Characteristics and outcomes of COVID-19 patients in association with asthma in difference age ARDS = Acute respiratory distress syndrome ¥: All reported p.values for categorical variable are calculated by logistic regression comparing variables in asthmatics with nonasthmatics adjusted for race, sex and body mass index(BMI) . Odds ratios (95%conficedence interval) are reported for these categorical variables. £: Reported p.values for continuous variables are calculated by comparing the adjusted means in asthmatics with non-asthmatics (adjusted for race, sex and body mass index [BMI]) via analysis of covariance (ANCOVA).
